title: Moral Money: 'As a non-believer, should I get christened to receive my inheritance?'
text:
I am from a traditionally Anglican family and when I was a baby my grandfather died and left me £3,000. However, it was not to be given to me until I was christened. My parents decided to let me make up my own mind about religion, and as I grew up to be agnostic I remain unchristened.

I am now 30 and want to buy a house, and the £3,000 would help. Would it be wrong to be christened just to get this money? I don't think my grandfather would object to the money being used for something that would genuinely help me.

HL, via email

This is not just a knotty moral situation, but one with considerable ecclesiastical tangles as well.
